{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3242433,"name":"Bekale","username":"Regis","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/77aa72/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-10-18T14:37:01.505Z","cooked":"

Hi,

Right now, my Swerve drive setup is as follow:

Setup 1

  • SDS MK4i
  • NEO drive and turn motors
  • NavX

Question 1:
Can I use the NEO internal encoders as a replacement for the CANcoders absolute encoders?

Setup 2

  • SDS MK4i
  • CANcoder absolute encoders
  • NEO drive and turn motors
  • Navx

Question 2:
Which one is the best setup options between option 1 and option 2? In both cases, is the Navx the right choice or the Pigeon 2.0 gyro?

Best Regards,

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2023-10-18T14:37:01.505Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":284,"reads":226,"readers_count":225,"score":1460.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":442674,"topic_slug":"best-setup-options-for-swerve-mk4i-neo-drive-and-turn-motors","display_username":"Bekale","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":36676,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/best-setup-options-for-swerve-mk4i-neo-drive-and-turn-motors/442674/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3242439,"name":"Finn B","username":"Nifley","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nifley/{size}/183092_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-18T14:54:20.741Z","cooked":"

I’m no expert on swerve drives by any means (our team just recently built and programmed our first swerve drive robot, NEOs and MK4i), but I don’t think the setup you have right now is really viable for swerve without absolute encoders.

To answer your first question, no, the NEO’s internal encoder isn’t a replacement for the CANcoder, but it can be used in addition to an absolute encoder. Having an absolute encoder is pretty essential because tells you the orientation of each swerve module when the robot is turned on, which means that you don’t need to calibrate each module every time you turn the robot on! What we did for our swerve drive was to use the CANcoder to get the module’s initial position and then use the NEO’s encoder after this initial calibration.

To answer your second question, the navX has worked just fine for us, I don’t see any reason to buy a Pigeon if you already have a navX.

The code for our swerve drive is here if you are interested.

Hi @Nifley ,

Thank you for your quick helpful feedback. I really appreciate it and will proceed as you suggested. I will probably need more help when we will be testing (for instance how to set the offset angles).

Take care !

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2023-10-18T15:07:15.639Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":11,"reads":178,"readers_count":177,"score":90.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":442674,"topic_slug":"best-setup-options-for-swerve-mk4i-neo-drive-and-turn-motors","display_username":"Bekale","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":56729,"username":"Nifley","name":"Finn B","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nifley/{size}/183092_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":36676,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/best-setup-options-for-swerve-mk4i-neo-drive-and-turn-motors/442674/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3242453,"name":"Lexeo","username":"Lexeo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lexeo/{size}/160041_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-18T15:22:30.420Z","cooked":"

Absolute encoders are important… but don’t really offer a performance increase between brands. For most teams, its about cost and wiring preference. I personally think the Thrifty Absolute encoder or Redux Helium Encoder are more economical choices, and easier to wire for most teams not heavily invested in the CTRE ecosystem. The Redux encoder plugs directly into a Spark Max too, which is nice.

If you choose not to use an absolute encoder, you cannot zero your modules automatically. You can manually zero them if you wanted. I think this is fine for at-home testing, but not great for competition.

As far as IMU, The NavX and Pigeon are both going to be fine. I think the pigeon 2.0 has better performance now, but am not 100% sure on that. Our reasoning for using the pigeon 2.0 is that we like using our Rio MXP port for other things.

If you are just trying to get something working, and you already have a NavX, that’s probably going to be fine.

Hi @Lexeo,

Thank you for your helpful insights. I will certainly consider your suggestions especially the simplicity of the wiring regarding the choice of the absolute encoders.

Thank you again and have a nice day!

Lexeo:

As far as IMU, The NavX and Pigeon are both going to be fine. I think the pigeon 2.0 has better performance now, but am not 100% sure on that. Our reasoning for using the pigeon 2.0 is that we like using our Rio MXP port for other things.

The navX2 and Pigeon 2.0 are comparable in terms of performance, IIRC (and might even use the same underlying IMU chip?). It’s more about form factor and communication preference than anything else.
